CHRISTUS HEALTH WILL HAVE 30 PUBLIC HEALTH AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL ADDRESS SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH BY PROVIDING OUTREACH, ASSISTING WITH NAVIGATION OF SERVICES, PROVIDINGEDUCATION, AND OFFERING REFERRALS TO PATIENTS TO IMPROVE HEALTH OUTCOMES IN THE PRIORITIES IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE 2023-2025 COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENTS (CHNA) ACROSS THE SERVICE AREAS OF CHRISTUS TRINITY MOTHER FRANCES, GOOD SHEPHERD, ST. MICHAEL, SANTA ROSA, SPOHN, SOUTHEAST TEXAS, OCHSNER ST. PATRICK, ST. FRANCIS CABRINI, SHREVEPORT-BOSSIER, ST. VINCENT AND SYSTEM OFFICE. AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE PUBLIC HEALTH AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ACQUIRING COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER (CHW) TRAINING AND STATE CERTIFICATION AND UTILIZATION OF A SOCIAL NEEDS COMMUNITY RESOURCE DIRECTORY. IN ADDITION, THE PUBLIC HEALTH AMERICORPS COMMUNITY HEALTH WORKER (PHACHW) MEMBERS WILL PARTNER WITH 6 CURRENT AMERICORPS VISTA MEMBERS WHO STRENGTHEN CHRISTUS HEALTH'S COMMUNITY HEALTH INFRASTRUCTURE BY MOBILIZING KEY INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO DEVELOP COALITIONS COMMITTED TO IMPROVING THE COMMUNITY'S HEALTH, DEVELOPING INTERVENTIONS TO ADDRESS COMMUNITY NEEDS AMONG HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS AS WELL AS IMPLEMENTING, MONITORING, AND EVALUATING COMMUNITY PROGRAMS. THE AMERICORPS INVESTMENT WILL BE MATCHED WITH $181,700; $0 IN PUBLIC FUNDING AND $181,700 IN PRIVATE FUNDING.

THIS AWARD FUNDS THE APPROVED 2023-24 PUBLIC HEALTH AMERICORPS PROGRAM. NO MEMBER MAY ENROLL PRIOR TO THE APPROVED START DATE OF THE MEMBER ENROLLMENT PERIOD. YOUR 2023-24 REGULATORY MATCH IS 0%. EQUAL HEART WILL HAVE 172 AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL PROVIDE ACCESS TO CARE AND OTHER SERVICES THAT MEET PUBLIC HEALTH NEEDS IN RURAL, DISTRESSED AND OTHER UNDER-RESOURCED COMMUNITIES ACROSS FIVE STATES, INCLUDING COLORADO, HAWAII, TEXAS, TENNESSEE, AND VIRGINIA. AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR INCREASING ACCESS TO CARE FOR 14,000 PEOPLE WITH A CHANGE IN BEHAVIOR LEADING TO AN INCREASE IN HEALTH OUTCOMES. IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE 300 WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN PROVIDING THESE SERVICES ALONGSIDE THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS.

WESTERN WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY/WASHINGTON CAMPUS COMPACT, SERVING AS AN INTERMEDIARY AND IN PARTNERSHIP WITH 42 OPERATING SITES IN WASHINGTON AND IDAHO PROPOSES THE CAMPUS CIVIC LEADERS AND ENGAGEMENT CORPS TO MOBILIZE 254 AMERICORPS MEMBERS (46 FT, 14, PT, 49 QT, 145 MT) TO ADDRESS CRITICAL COMMUNITY ISSUES THAT WERE EXACERBATED BY COVID-19 IN THE AREAS OF EDUCATION, HEALTHY FUTURES AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. 87 AMERICORPS MEMBERS (45 MSY) WILL PROVIDE ACADEMIC AND SUPPORT SERVICES COACHING, AND ORGANIZE SERVICE-LEARNING INTERVENTIONS TO IMPROVE ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT OF UNDERREPRESENTED (RACIAL/ETHNIC AND SOCIOECONOMIC) K-16 STUDENTS; 58 AMERICORPS MEMBERS (17 MSY) WILL PROVIDE COVID-19 VACCINATION PROGRAM SUPPORT, AND MEDICAL/MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES ACCESS TO UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS; 104 AMERICORPS MEMBERS (29 MSY) WILL COLLECT AND DISTRIBUTE FOOD, AND PROVIDE OUTREACH, REFERRALS, AND COUNSELING/COACHING TO PEOPLE EXPERIENCING FOOD INSECURITY; AND FIVE AMERICORPS MEMBER (5 MSY) WILL IMPLEMENT ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP INTERVENTIONS. AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR 1. SERVING 1,575 UNDERREPRESENTED K-16 STUDENTS, OF WHICH, 80% WILL REPORT IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT; 2. PROVIDING ACCESS TO MEDICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES TO 850 COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND STUDENTS; 3. COLLECT AND DISTRIBUTE 7000 POUNDS OF FOOD, AND PROVIDE FOOD SECURITY SUPPORT TO 600 PEOPLE; AND 4. TREATING 130 ACRES OF PUBLIC AND TRIBAL LANDS. IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE 2,125 STUDENT CIVIC LEADER VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL SERVE WITH THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS TO IMPLEMENT THE INTERVENTIONS. THIS PROGRAM WILL ADDRESS THE CNCS FOCUS AREAS OF EDUCATION, HEALTHY FUTURES, AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $1,575,395 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $960,500 IN OTHER REVENUE AND IN-KIND SUPPORT.

THE NATIONAL COLLEGE ADVISING CORPS PROPOSES TO HAVE 265 AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL PROVIDE COLLEGE ADVISING TO LOW-INCOME, FIRST-GENERATION, UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS IN UNDERSERVED HIGH SCHOOLS IN MARKETS SUCH AS DETROIT, CHICAGO, ATLANTA, ST. LOUIS, PHILADELPHIA, AND KANSAS CITY. AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR INCREASING THE COLLEGE ENROLLMENT RATES AMONG ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED YOUTH AT THE HIGH SCHOOLS SERVED. THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $4,319,500 WILL BE MATCHED WITH $10,532,000, $750,000 IN PUBLIC FUNDING AND $9,782,000 IN PRIVATE FUNDING.

CONSERVATION CORPS PROPOSES TO HAVE 96 AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL CARRY OUT CONSERVATION SERVICE LEARNING IN MINNESOTA, IOWA, WISCONSIN, NORTH DAKOTA, MISSOURI, AND AROUND THE MIDWEST. AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR 15,000 ACRES OF VITAL HABITAT RESTORED; 400 MILES OF TRAIL AND/OR WATERWAY CREATED OR IMPROVED; AND 88 MEMBERS TRAINED, EQUIPPED AND AVAILABLE TO RESPOND TO DISASTERS. IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE 575 VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN RIVER CLEAN-UPS, RAIN GARDEN INSTALLATIONS, AND TREE PLANTING EVENTS.

THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREA OF ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $1,536,000 WILL BE MATCHED WITH $1,920,172, $1,603,650 IN PUBLIC FUNDING AND $316,522 IN PRIVATE FUNDING.

THE MONTANA CONSERVATION CORPS (MCC) PROPOSES TO HAVE 378 AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL PROTECT AT-RISK ECOSYSTEMS AND IMPROVE PARKS, PUBLIC LANDS, TRAILS AND RIVERS TO BENEFIT COMMUNITIES ACROSS MONTANA, IDAHO, WYOMING, NORTH DAKOTA AND SOUTH DAKOTA.  AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR IMPROVING 950 MILES OF TRAILS AND RIVERS AND 8,500 ACRES OF PUBLIC LANDS. AMERICORPS MEMBERS ALSO WILL LEAD 130 LOCAL YOUTH ON SUMMER SERVICE EXPEDITIONS TO IMPROVE TRAILS AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS FOR ENVIRONMENTALLY-CONSCIOUS PRACTICES.  MEMBERS MAY DEPLOY ON FEMA-AUTHORIZED MISSIONS AS PART OF THE AMERICORPS DISASTER RESPONSE TEAM. IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE 1,000 VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN IMPROVING PUBLIC LANDS AND TRAILS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. 
   THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREAS OF ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AND DISASTER SERVICES. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $1,994,000 WILL BE MATCHED WITH $5,100,000; $3,849,000 IN PUBLIC FUNDING AND $1,251,000 IN PRIVATE FUNDING.

THE CONSERVATION LEGACY PROPOSES TO HAVE 817 AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL IMPROVE TRAILS AND WATERWAYS, IMPROVE DEGRADED HABITAT AND UNHEALTHY FORESTS, PROVIDE DISASTER RESPONSE SERVICES, TRAIN YOUNG AMERICANS IN NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES AND INCREASE OUR NATION'S RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE IMPACTS IN AZ, CO, NM, WV, VA, NC AND TN. AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR IMPROVING 16,058 ACRES OF LAND, IMPROVING 2,545 MILES OF TRAILS OR RIVERS AND PROVIDING DISASTER ASSISTANCE TO 400 INDIVIDUALS. IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE 300 VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN SERVICE DAYS ON PUBLIC LANDS AND PARKS. THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREAS OF ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AND DISASTER RESPONSE. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $2,470,425.00  WILL BE MATCHED WITH $13,348,571.43, $12,013,714.29  IN PUBLIC FUNDING AND $1,334,857.14 IN PRIVATE FUNDING.

THE CORPS NETWORK (TCN) PROPOSES TO HAVE 2,552 AMERICORPS MEMBERS (FOR A TOTAL OF 1094.85 MSY) WHO WILL COMPLETE ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS IN HUNDREDS OF COMMUNITIES ACROSS 41 STATES AND DC. 2018-2019 SYNOPSIS OF THE ARIZONA AMERICORPS STATE REQUEST FOR GRANT APPLICATION PROCESS 

THE GOVERNOR'S COMMISSION ON SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERISM (THE COMMISSION) WAS FOUNDED IN 1994 TO PROVIDE OVERSIGHT AND ADMINISTER THE GRANT-MAKING PROCESS FOR AMERICORPS STATE PROGRAMS IN ARIZONA. THIS PUBLIC AND COMPETITIVE GRANT-MAKING PROCESS DETERMINED THOSE APPLICATIONS THAT MEET FUNDING REQUIREMENTS SET BY THE GOVERNOR'S OFFICE FOR YOUTH, FAITH AND FAMILY (GOYFF) AND BY ARIZONA STATE PROCUREMENT. ORGANIZATIONS SUBMIT AN APPLICATION IDENTIFYING A SIGNIFICANT COMMUNITY ISSUES AND EVIDENCE BASED INTERVENTIONS FOR WHICH AMERICORPS MEMBERS ARE ENGAGED TO STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND COMMUNITY IMPACT. 

THE REQUEST FOR GRANT APPLICATION (RFGA) WAS DEVELOPED IN FEBRUARY, 2018, BY THE AMERICORPS STATE PROGRAM TEAM, INCLUDING THE DIRECTOR OF THE COMMISSION ON SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERISM, THE DIRECTOR OF GOYFF, AND THE GOVERNOR?S ACCOUNTING OFFICE. THE 2018 CNCS NOTICE OF GRANT FUNDING (NOFO), APPLICATION INSTRUCTIONS, AND PERFORMANCE MEASURE INSTRUCTIONS CONSTITUTE THE FOUNDATION OF THE RFGA AND ARE CITED THROUGHOUT THE DOCUMENT. THE COMMISSION REVIEWED AND APPROVED THE FUNDING STRATEGY FOR MAKING THE MOST OF AVAILABLE COMPETITIVE AMERICORPS RESOURCES. A NOTIFICATION OF THE REQUEST FOR GRANT APPLICATIONS (RFGA) # AC-VSG-18-090118-00 WAS DISTRIBUTED AND POSTED TO THE GOYFF GRANTS WEB PAGE IN APRIL 2018.

APPLICATIONS WERE DUE ON MAY 10, 2018, AND FIFTEEN (15) APPLICATIONS WERE SUBMITTED FOR THE FORMULA FUNDING. THE APPLICATIONS WERE EVALUATED PURSUANT TO THE OFFICIAL EVALUATION CRITERIA PUBLISHED IN THE RFGA AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PROCEDURES UTILIZED BY ARIZONA STATE PROCUREMENT AND THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL COMMUNITY SERVICE'S NOFO.  

THE GRANT APPLICATIONS AND EVALUATION GUIDELINES WERE DISTRIBUTED TO MEMBERS OF THE CONSENSUS REVIEW COMMITTEE ON MAY 11, 2018. THE CONSENSUS REVIEW COMMITTEE MEMBERS INCLUDED 3 COMMISSION STAFF, 1 COMMISSIONER, AND 2 MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC. THE THREE COMMISSION STAFF ACTED AS REVIEWERS AND TECHNICAL ADVISORS. A REVIEWER TRAINING WAS HELD ON MAY 9, 2018 AT WHICH TIME THE RFGA, EVALUATION TOOL AND EVALUATOR GUIDELINES WERE REVIEWED. DURING THIS TRAINING, ALL REVIEWERS INCLUDING

REVIEWERS WERE REQUIRED TO SIGN A CONFIDENTIALITY AND CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT.   THE APPLICATIONS THAT WERE SUBMITTED REFLECT A GEOGRAPHICALLY DISPERSED PORTFOLIO FOR WHICH A MAJORITY OF APPLICATIONS ADDRESS ONE OR MORE OF THE GOVERNOR?S PRIORITY OR DEMONSTRATION AREAS. ADDITIONALLY, PROGRAM APPLICATIONS INCLUDE IMPORTANT ELEMENTS AND REQUIREMENTS AS STATED IN THE CNCS APPLICATION GUIDANCE AS ALIGNED WITH THE NOFO. APPLICATIONS ALSO ADDRESS KEY PRIORITIES OF DOUGLAS A. DUCEY, GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF ARIZONA, INCLUDING EIGHTH GRADE MATH, HIGH SCHOOL COMPLETION, THIRD GRADE READING PROFICIENCY, OPIOID EPIDEMIC, AND VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN AND WILDFIRE REDUCTION.

AT A MEETING HELD IN PHOENIX, ARIZONA ON JUNE 27, 2018, THE COMMISSION UNANIMOUSLY VOTED TO MOVE THE APPLICATIONS FORWARD FOR THE SUBMITTAL TO THE CNCS FOR CONSIDERATION OF FORMULA FUNDING.

OHIO AMERICORPS PROGRAMS WILL ENGAGE INDIVIDUALS IN A YEAR OF SERVICE ADDRESSING CRITICAL NEEDS IDENTIFIED THROUGH COMMUNITY PROCESSES.  AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL SERVE WITH NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, COMMUNITY-BASED AGENCIES, SCHOOLS, UNIVERSITIES, AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES TO MEET NEEDS RELATED TO EDUCATION, VETERANS/MILITARY FAMILIES, ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY, HEALTHY FUTURES, AND DISASTER PREPAREDNESS.

SERVERMONT PROVIDED ALL THE APPLICATIONS THAT WERE SUBMITTED TO COMMISSIONERS FOR REVIEW, ALONG WITH COMPETITION MATERIALS FROM CNCS, AND A GUIDE TO REVIEWING APPLICATIONS. 
COMMISSIONERS REVIEWED APPLICATIONS AND PREPARED FEEDBACK.  STAFF AND COMMISSIONERS DISCUSSED APPLICATIONS AT A COMMISSION MEETING AND A LIST OF FEEDBACK FOR EACH APPLICANT WAS COMPLIED, AND THEN PROVIDED TO THE APPLICANT FOR THEIR CONSIDERATION.  APPLICANTS MADE ENHANCEMENTS AND CHANGES TO THEIR APPLICATION BASED UPON THE FEEDBACK, AND RESUBMITTED APPLICATIONS. THE COMMISSION RANKED THE APPLICATIONS DURING A COMMISSION MEETING BASED ON THE COMPARABLE QUALITY OF THE APPLICATION, PAST PERFORMANCE INCLUDING ENROLLMENT AND RETENTION, AND COMMUNITY NEED. APPLICATIONS PERCEIVED TO BE STRONGER, FULFILL A UNIQUE COMMUNITY NEED (POPULATION SERVED, PRESSING PROBLEM, UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY, GEOGRAPHIC REGION), OR HAVE STRONG PROGRAM PERFORMANCE WERE RANKED HIGHER.
THIS APPLICATION IS FOR NEW, RECOMPETING, OR CONTINUATION STATE COMMISSION APPLICANTS, INCLUDING TERRITORIES WITH COMMISSIONS, APPLYING FOR COST REIMBURSEMENT GRANTS.

IF A PROPOSAL MET THE MINIMUM CRITERIA, IT WAS REVIEWED AND SCORED BY TWO READERS SELECTED BY THE COMMISSION. THESE READERS WERE ASKED TO AGREE ON A CONSENSUS SCORE SHEET THAT WAS USED TO RANK PROPOSALS. THE SCORE SHEET ALIGNED WITH THE OUTLINE AND POINTS VALUES SPECIFIED IN THE NEW YORK STATE RFP.  IF THE TWO READERS COULD NOT COME TO CONSENSUS, A THIRD READER WAS ASKED TO REVIEW THE PROPOSAL AND TO WORK WITH THE ORIGINAL TWO READERS TO SUBMIT A CONSENSUS SCORE SHEET.   THE REVIEWERS THEN SUBMITTED THEIR CONSENSUS SCORE SHEETS FOR EACH PROPOSAL TO THE COMMISSION WHICH WERE RANKED ACCORDING TO SCORE FROM HIGHEST TO LOWEST. AFTER EVALUATING THE PROPOSALS, THE COMMISSION CONSIDERED AND AUTOMATICALLY RECOMMENDED APPLICATIONS THAT RECEIVED A TOTAL SCORE OF 90 OR ABOVE FOR FUNDING. APPLICATIONS THAT RECEIVED A TOTAL SCORE BETWEEN 70 AND 89 WERE, WITHIN THE DISCRETION OF THE COMMISSION, RECOMMENDED FOR FUNDING. APPLICATIONS SCORING BELOW A TOTAL OF 70 POINTS WERE NOT RECOMMENDED FOR FUNDING.

THE PROGRAMMING PROPOSED IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE GEOGRAPHIC DIVERSITY OF THE STATE'S AMERICORPS PORTFOLIO, INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES TO SERVE IN AMERICORPS AND/OR TO RECEIVE AMERICORPS SERVICES, OR FOCUS ON A NEED NOT OTHERWISE ADDRESSED IN ITS AMERICORPS PROGRAMMING.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
THE MARYLAND GOVERNOR'S OFFICE ON SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERISM (GOSV) IS PROUD TO PRESENT THIS PACKAGE OF SEVEN CONTINUATION APPLICATIONS FOR THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE'S (CNCS) 2018 AMERICORPS STATE AND NATIONAL GRANT COMPETITION. THESE PROGRAMS WILL ENGAGE 366.17 MSYS, INVEST $1.7 MILLION IN FEDERAL AMERICORPS FUNDS, AND LEVERAGE $3.5 MILLION IN STATE AND LOCAL FUNDS IN MARYLAND COMMUNITIES. 
THIS PACKAGE IS THE RESULT OF EXTENSIVE APPLICATION REVIEW AND REFINEMENT CONDUCTED BY THE GOSV STAFF AND THE MEMBERS OF THE MARYLAND GOVERNOR'S COMMISSION ON SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERISM (GCOSV) BETWEEN SEPTEMBER 11, 2017 AND JANUARY 16, 2018. TOGETHER, THESE PROGRAMS WILL ADDRESS CNCS PRIORITIES IN THE AREAS OF ADDRESSING THE OPIOID AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG ABUSE CRISIS, ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT FOR STUDENTS IN TWO OF THE LOWEST PERFORMING SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN MARYLAND (BALTIMORE CITY AND PRINCE GEORGE'S COUNTY), ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, CAPACITY BUILDING FOR NONPROFIT SERVICE AGENCIES, HEALTH AND NUTRITION SERVICES FOR YOUTH, AND MORE.
THESE APPLICATIONS REPRESENT PROGRAMS THAT WILL SERVE EVERY CORNER OF THE STATE AND ENGAGE DIVERSE AMERICORPS MEMBERS AND LOCAL VOLUNTEERS IN TACKLING THE MOST CRITICAL HUMAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL NEEDS OF MARYLAND COMMUNITIES. THEY WILL ALSO PROVIDE TRANSFORMATIONAL AMERICORPS SERVICE EXPERIENCES AND SIGNIFICANT ORGANIZATIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR HOST SITE PARTNER AGENCIES. EACH OF THE SEVEN CONTINUATION PROGRAMS HAS A STRONG TRACK RECORD AND MEETS OR EXCEEDS CNCS-REQUIRED ANNUAL FUNDING MATCH LEVELS FOR THE AMERICORPS GRANTS. FROM THE RESEARCH-BASED, TRAUMA-INFORMED STRATEGIES OF OUR NEW TARGETED PRIORITY PROGRAMS, HOPECORPS AND COAT TO THE STATE-WIDE REACH OF THE MARYLAND CONSERVATION CORPS AND VOLUNTEER MARYLAND, TO THE TARGETED COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT WORK OF CIVIC WORKS, AND THE INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO IMPROVING STUDENT ACHIEVEMENT AND ENGAGEMENT OF READING PARTNERS AND TEACH FOR AMERICA, THESE PROGRAMS PROVIDE INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS THAT ENGAGE HUNDREDS OF LOCAL COMMUNITY PARTNERS, PUBLIC OFFICIALS, AND FUNDERS, AND THOUSANDS OF COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS. WITH THE BREADTH OF THE ISSUES ADDRESSED, THESE PROGRAMS WILL ALSO IMPACT THE HEALTH OF COMMUNITIES AND CITIZENS BEYOND MARYLAND'S BORDERS (E.G. CHESAPEAKE BAY WATERSHED, PROFESSIONAL VOLUNTEER MANAGEMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, GREEN ENERGY, ORGANIC AND SUSTAINABLE FARMING, AND MORE).

THE GOVERNOR'S COMMISSION ON COMMUNITY AND VOLUNTEER SERVICE IS VERY PROUD TO SUBMIT TWO OUTSTANDING COMPETITIVE APPLICATIONS FOR THE 2021-2022 AMERICORPS PROGRAM YEAR.

THE DREAM PROGRAM, INC. IF A PROPOSAL MET THE MINIMUM CRITERIA, IT WAS REVIEWED AND SCORED BY TWO READERS SELECTED BY THE COMMISSION. THESE READERS WERE ASKED TO AGREE ON A CONSENSUS SCORE SHEET THAT WAS USED TO RANK PROPOSALS. THE SCORE SHEET ALIGNED WITH THE OUTLINE AND POINTS VALUES SPECIFIED IN THE NEW YORK STATE RFP.  IF THE TWO READERS COULD NOT COME TO CONSENSUS, A THIRD READER WAS ASKED TO REVIEW THE PROPOSAL AND TO WORK WITH THE ORIGINAL TWO READERS TO SUBMIT A CONSENSUS SCORE SHEET.   THE REVIEWERS THEN SUBMITTED THEIR CONSENSUS SCORE SHEETS FOR EACH PROPOSAL TO THE COMMISSION WHICH WERE RANKED ACCORDING TO SCORE FROM HIGHEST TO LOWEST. AFTER EVALUATING THE PROPOSALS, THE COMMISSION CONSIDERED AND AUTOMATICALLY RECOMMENDED APPLICATIONS THAT RECEIVED A TOTAL SCORE OF 90 OR ABOVE FOR FUNDING. APPLICATIONS THAT RECEIVED A TOTAL SCORE BETWEEN 70 AND 89 WERE, WITHIN THE DISCRETION OF THE COMMISSION, RECOMMENDED FOR FUNDING. APPLICATIONS SCORING BELOW A TOTAL OF 70 POINTS WERE NOT RECOMMENDED FOR FUNDING.

THE PROGRAMMING PROPOSED IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE GEOGRAPHIC DIVERSITY OF THE STATE'S AMERICORPS PORTFOLIO, INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES TO SERVE IN AMERICORPS AND/OR TO RECEIVE AMERICORPS SERVICES, OR FOCUS ON A NEED NOT OTHERWISE ADDRESSED IN ITS AMERICORPS PROGRAMMING.
THIS APPLICATION IS FOR NEW, RECOMPETING, OR CONTINUATION COMMISSION APPLICANTS, INCLUDING TERRITORIES WITH COMMISSIONS, APPLYING FOR FIXED AMOUNT GRANTS (INCLUDING EAP).

OUR CALIFORNIANS FOR ALL VISTA PROJECT ADDRESSES FOOD SECURITY WITHIN THE CNCS?S HEALTHY FUTURES FOCUS AREA. VISTA MEMBERS REQUESTED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE CAPACITY OF CRITICAL PARTNERS THAT SERVE LOW-INCOME AND VULNERABLE POPULATIONS TO MEET INCREASING DEMAND FOR PROGRAM SERVICES THROUGH SUSTAINED VOLUNTEER SUPPORT. VISTA MEMBERS WILL ASSIST THOSE ORGANIZATIONS IN GENERATING VOLUNTEERS AND ESTABLISHING NEW OR ENHANCED VOLUNTEER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO ENSURE LONG-TERM PROGRAM VIABILITY. AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, CALIFORNIANS LIVING IN POVERTY WILL HAVE GREATER ACCESS TO THE HELP THEY NEED AS NONPROFITS AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES ACROSS CALIFORNIA UTILIZE VOLUNTEERS MORE EFFECTIVELY TO EXPAND AND IMPROVE SERVICES. CALIFORNIA VOLUNTEERS IS REQUESTING 60 VISTA MEMBERS  (54 MEMBERS, 6 PROJECT LEADS) TO SERVE FOR 1 YEAR.

PLANNING GRANT: IN ORDER TO ADVANCE COLLEGE, CAREER, AND CIVIC READINESS IN THE MARYLAND, DC, AND DELAWARE (MID-ATLANTIC) REGION BY STRENGTHENING P20 (K12-HIGHER EDUCATION) PARTNERSHIPS, CAMPUS COMPACT MID-ATLANTIC (CCMA) PROPOSES TO RESEARCH ALL ASPECTS OF AN AMERICORPS PROGRAM THAT WOULD BUILD AN AFFILIATE REGION OF THE INTERNATIONALLY ACCLAIMED PEACEJAM PROGRAM.  THIS WOULD INCLUDE INTRODUCING PEACEJAM ACADEMIC CURRICULA IN K12 SCHOOLS, PROVIDING AN ANNUAL PEACEJAM YOUTH CONFERENCE HOSTED BY A NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WINNER, AND BUILDING A LEADERSHIP AND SERVICE PROGRAM ON MULTIPLE COLLEGE CAMPUSES THAT WILL ADDRESS THE CNCS FOCUS AREAS OF EDUCATION AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY. PEACEJAM PROVIDES A BROAD RANGE OF EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOCUSED ON THE WORK OF NOBEL PEACE LAUREATES THAT FOSTER ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND BUILD COMPASSIONATE LEADERS. ALL PEACEJAM PARTICIPANTS ENGAGE IN EVIDENCE-INFORMED HIGH-QUALITY ACADEMIC SERVICE-LEARNING. RESEARCH FROM THE PEACEJAM NATIONAL EVALUATION INDICATES THAT YOUTH PARTICIPATING IN PEACEJAM SCORE HIGHER IN MEASURES OF ACADEMIC AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT AND STANDARDIZED TESTS THAN THEIR NON-PARTICIPATING PEERS. THE CCMA PROJECT WILL PARTNER WITH THE PEACEJAM FOUNDATION, HEADQUARTERED IN COLORADO WITH AFFILIATES THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES AND IN FORTY COUNTRIES AROUND THE WORLD. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $74,704.20 IN PUBLIC FUNDING WILL BE MATCHED WITH $23,415.59 IN MATCH FUNDING ($10,930 PRIVATE / $12,536.59 PUBLIC). NO AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE NEEDED TO EXECUTE THIS PLAN AS THIS WILL BE THE PLANNING GRANT YEAR. ACTIONS PLANNED INCLUDE RESEARCHING SUCCESSFUL AMERICORPS PROGRAMS; MAINTAINING A DIVERSE PLANNING TEAM; WORKING CLOSELY WITH CNCS PROGRAM OFFICERS; PARTNERING WITH STATE SERVICE COMMISSIONS; RECRUITING UNIVERSITY/COLLEGE PARTNERS; RECRUITING K12 CURRICULUM PARTNERS; AND DEVELOPING A COMPREHENSIVE PLAN FOR ORIENTATION, TRAINING AND SUPPORT OF AMERICORPS MEMBERS.

1. MAINE CONSERVATION CORPS (ID: 18ES199929) WHO  REQUESTS $660,224 WITH 49.16 MSY (109 MEMBERS) ENGAGED IN SERVICE TO ADDRESS ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP ISSUES IN COMMUNITIES ACROSS MAINE.

RANKING JUSTIFICATION NARRATIVE: THIS GRANT TYPE HAS ONLY ONE PROPOSAL SO THE JUSTIFICATION FIELD IS NOT APPEARING. AT THE TIME OF SUBMISSION, EGRANTS HELP IS UNABLE TO SOLVE THE ISSUE. THEREFORE, THE RANKING JUSTIFICATION TEXT IS BELOW:

THE NEW APPLICATION WAS SELECTED FOR SUBMISSION USING A TWO-STEP CONSENSUS PROCESS THAT INCORPORATES CNCS REQUIREMENTS, COMMISSION POLICIES ON FUNDING AND PERFORMANCE AND THE REQUIREMENTS OF STATE CONTRACT SELECTION RULES. AMERICORPS PROGRAM PROPOSALS ARE ASSESSED BY THE COMMISSION'S GRANT SELECTION AND PERFORMANCE TASK FORCE USING A TWO-STEP REVIEW PROCESS.
1) EXTERNAL PEER REVIEW OF APPLICATION NARRATIVES BASED ON WRITTEN CONTENT AND THE POINTS INDICATED IN THE CNCS NOFO, AND; 
2) TASK FORCE ASSESSMENT OF APPLICANT'S ADEQUACY OF FINANCIAL SYSTEMS, BUDGET, AND MATCH.

UNDER STATE OF MAINE PROCUREMENT RULES, IF THERE IS MORE THAN ONE APPLICATION IN A NEW COMPETITION FOR A GRANT CATEGORY, THE PROPOSAL SCORING THE HIGHEST POINTS MUST BE RANKED #1, SECOND HIGHEST SCORE MUST BE RANKED #2, AND SO FORTH. IN THIS CASE, THERE IS ONLY ONE NEW APPLICATION.

CONTINUATION APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED BY A PANEL OF COMMISSION MEMBERS WHO ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR ASSESSING GRANT PERFORMANCE. USING A RUBRIC FOR SCORING, THEY CONSIDER PERFORMANCE INDICATORS (ENROLLMENT, RETENTION, 30-DAY ON TIME, ETC.), COMPLIANCE, ACHIEVEMENT OF PERFORMANCE MEASURE TARGETS, FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE AND SPONSOR AUDIT, AND MORE. BASED ON THE RESULTS, THE COMMISSIONERS HAVE THE OPTION TO SUPPORT THE REQUEST AS SUBMITTED OR REDUCE THE REQUEST OR DENY THE REQUEST/END THE GRANT. UNDER MAINE STATE PROCUREMENT RULES, NO RANKING IS PERMITTED FOR CONTINUATIONS OF MULTI-YEAR GRANTS.

2018-2019 SYNOPSIS OF THE ARIZONA AMERICORPS STATE REQUEST FOR GRANT APPLICATION PROCESS 

THE GOVERNOR'S COMMISSION ON SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERISM (THE COMMISSION) WAS FOUNDED IN 1994 TO PROVIDE OVERSIGHT AND ADMINISTER THE GRANT-MAKING PROCESS FOR AMERICORPS STATE PROGRAMS IN ARIZONA. THIS PUBLIC AND COMPETITIVE GRANT-MAKING PROCESS DETERMINED THOSE APPLICATIONS THAT MEET FUNDING REQUIREMENTS SET BY THE GOVERNOR'S OFFICE FOR YOUTH, FAITH AND FAMILY (GOYFF) AND BY ARIZONA STATE PROCUREMENT. ORGANIZATIONS SUBMIT AN APPLICATION IDENTIFYING A SIGNIFICANT COMMUNITY ISSUES AND EVIDENCE BASED INTERVENTIONS FOR WHICH AMERICORPS MEMBERS ARE ENGAGED TO STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND COMMUNITY IMPACT. 

THE REQUEST FOR GRANT APPLICATION (RFGA) WAS DEVELOPED IN FEBRUARY, 2018, BY THE AMERICORPS STATE PROGRAM TEAM, INCLUDING THE DIRECTOR OF THE COMMISSION ON SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERISM, THE DIRECTOR OF GOYFF, AND THE GOVERNOR?S ACCOUNTING OFFICE. THE 2018 CNCS NOTICE OF GRANT FUNDING (NOFO), APPLICATION INSTRUCTIONS, AND PERFORMANCE MEASURE INSTRUCTIONS CONSTITUTE THE FOUNDATION OF THE RFGA AND ARE CITED THROUGHOUT THE DOCUMENT. THE COMMISSION REVIEWED AND APPROVED THE FUNDING STRATEGY FOR MAKING THE MOST OF AVAILABLE COMPETITIVE AMERICORPS RESOURCES. A NOTIFICATION OF THE REQUEST FOR GRANT APPLICATIONS (RFGA) # AC-VSG-18-090118-00 WAS DISTRIBUTED AND POSTED TO THE GOYFF GRANTS WEB PAGE IN APRIL 2018.

APPLICATIONS WERE DUE ON MAY 10, 2018, AND FIFTEEN (15) APPLICATIONS WERE SUBMITTED FOR THE FORMULA FUNDING. THE APPLICATIONS WERE EVALUATED PURSUANT TO THE OFFICIAL EVALUATION CRITERIA PUBLISHED IN THE RFGA AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PROCEDURES UTILIZED BY ARIZONA STATE PROCUREMENT AND THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL COMMUNITY SERVICE'S NOFO.  

THE GRANT APPLICATIONS AND EVALUATION GUIDELINES WERE DISTRIBUTED TO MEMBERS OF THE CONSENSUS REVIEW COMMITTEE ON MAY 11, 2018. THE CONSENSUS REVIEW COMMITTEE MEMBERS INCLUDED 3 COMMISSION STAFF, 1 COMMISSIONER, AND 2 MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC. THE THREE COMMISSION STAFF ACTED AS REVIEWERS AND TECHNICAL ADVISORS. A REVIEWER TRAINING WAS HELD ON MAY 9, 2018 AT WHICH TIME THE RFGA, EVALUATION TOOL AND EVALUATOR GUIDELINES WERE REVIEWED. DURING THIS TRAINING, ALL REVIEWERS INCLUDING

REVIEWERS WERE REQUIRED TO SIGN A CONFIDENTIALITY AND CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT.   THE APPLICATIONS THAT WERE SUBMITTED REFLECT A GEOGRAPHICALLY DISPERSED PORTFOLIO FOR WHICH A MAJORITY OF APPLICATIONS ADDRESS ONE OR MORE OF THE GOVERNOR?S PRIORITY OR DEMONSTRATION AREAS. ADDITIONALLY, PROGRAM APPLICATIONS INCLUDE IMPORTANT ELEMENTS AND REQUIREMENTS AS STATED IN THE CNCS APPLICATION GUIDANCE AS ALIGNED WITH THE NOFO. APPLICATIONS ALSO ADDRESS KEY PRIORITIES OF DOUGLAS A. DUCEY, GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF ARIZONA, INCLUDING EIGHTH GRADE MATH, HIGH SCHOOL COMPLETION, THIRD GRADE READING PROFICIENCY, OPIOID EPIDEMIC, AND VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN AND WILDFIRE REDUCTION.

AT A MEETING HELD IN PHOENIX, ARIZONA ON JUNE 27, 2018, THE COMMISSION UNANIMOUSLY VOTED TO MOVE THE APPLICATIONS FORWARD FOR THE SUBMITTAL TO THE CNCS FOR CONSIDERATION OF FORMULA FUNDING.

SERVERMONT PROVIDED ALL THE APPLICATIONS THAT WERE SUBMITTED TO COMMISSIONERS FOR REVIEW, ALONG WITH COMPETITION MATERIALS FROM CNCS, AND A GUIDE TO REVIEWING APPLICATIONS. 
COMMISSIONERS REVIEWED APPLICATIONS AND PREPARED FEEDBACK.  STAFF AND COMMISSIONERS DISCUSSED APPLICATIONS AT A COMMISSION MEETING AND A LIST OF FEEDBACK FOR EACH APPLICANT WAS COMPLIED, AND THEN PROVIDED TO THE APPLICANT FOR THEIR CONSIDERATION.  APPLICANTS MADE ENHANCEMENTS AND CHANGES TO THEIR APPLICATION BASED UPON THE FEEDBACK, AND RESUBMITTED APPLICATIONS. THE COMMISSION RANKED THE APPLICATIONS DURING A COMMISSION MEETING BASED ON THE COMPARABLE QUALITY OF THE APPLICATION, PAST PERFORMANCE INCLUDING ENROLLMENT AND RETENTION, AND COMMUNITY NEED. APPLICATIONS PERCEIVED TO BE STRONGER, FULFILL A UNIQUE COMMUNITY NEED (POPULATION SERVED, PRESSING PROBLEM, UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY, GEOGRAPHIC REGION), OR HAVE STRONG PROGRAM PERFORMANCE WERE RANKED HIGHER.

IF A PROPOSAL MET THE MINIMUM CRITERIA, IT WAS REVIEWED AND SCORED BY TWO READERS SELECTED BY THE COMMISSION. THESE READERS WERE ASKED TO AGREE ON A CONSENSUS SCORE SHEET THAT WAS USED TO RANK PROPOSALS. THE SCORE SHEET ALIGNED WITH THE OUTLINE AND POINTS VALUES SPECIFIED IN THE NEW YORK STATE RFP.  IF THE TWO READERS COULD NOT COME TO CONSENSUS, A THIRD READER WAS ASKED TO REVIEW THE PROPOSAL AND TO WORK WITH THE ORIGINAL TWO READERS TO SUBMIT A CONSENSUS SCORE SHEET.   THE REVIEWERS THEN SUBMITTED THEIR CONSENSUS SCORE SHEETS FOR EACH PROPOSAL TO THE COMMISSION WHICH WERE RANKED ACCORDING TO SCORE FROM HIGHEST TO LOWEST. AFTER EVALUATING THE PROPOSALS, THE COMMISSION RECOMMENDED THE TOP 50 PERCENT OF ALL PROPOSALS SCORED FOR FUNDING TO THE CORPORATION, AS THE PROGRAMMING PROPOSED WOULD INCREASE GEOGRAPHIC DIVERSITY OF THE STATE'S AMERICORPS PORTFOLIO, INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES TO SERVE IN AMERICORPS AND/OR TO RECEIVE AMERICORPS SERVICES, OR FOCUS ON A NEED NOT OTHERWISE ADDRESSED IN ITS AMERICORPS PROGRAMMING.  THE COMMISSION HAS RANKED ITS TOP FIVE PROPOSALS BASED ON OUR REVIEW PROCESS. THE COMMISSION HAS ALSO SUBMITTED PROPOSALS BY GRAND STREET SETTLEMENT AND THE AMERICAN RED CROSS OF NORTHEASTERN NEW YORK. THESE TWO PROPOSALS RECEIVED IDENTICAL SCORES AND RANKED JUST BELOW THE FIVE PROPOSALS RANKED IN EGRANTS; AS EGRANTS DOES NOT ALLOW THE COMMISSION TO SUBMIT TIED RANKINGS, WE NOTE THEIR RANKINGS HERE.

REPEAT OF RANK NARRATIVE (EGRANTS DBASE IS ACTING UP SO ENTERING THIS HERE IN CASE IT CONTINUES TO RECORD ONLY PART OF THE TEXT):
THE NEW APPLICATION WAS SELECTED FOR SUBMISSION USING A TWO-STEP CONSENSUS PROCESS THAT INCORPORATES CNCS REQUIREMENTS, COMMISSION POLICIES ON FUNDING AND PERFORMANCE AND THE REQUIREMENTS OF STATE CONTRACT SELECTION RULES. AMERICORPS PROGRAM PROPOSALS ARE ASSESSED BY THE COMMISSION'S GRANT SELECTION AND PERFORMANCE TASK FORCE USING A TWO-STEP REVIEW PROCESS.
1) EXTERNAL PEER REVIEW OF APPLICATION NARRATIVES BASED ON WRITTEN CONTENT AND THE POINTS INDICATED IN THE CNCS NOFO, AND; 
2) TASK FORCE ASSESSMENT OF APPLICANT'S ADEQUACY OF FINANCIAL SYSTEMS, BUDGET, AND MATCH.

UNDER STATE OF MAINE PROCUREMENT RULES, IF THERE IS MORE THAN ONE APPLICATION IN A NEW COMPETITION FOR A GRANT CATEGORY, THE PROPOSAL SCORING THE HIGHEST POINTS MUST BE RANKED #1, SECOND HIGHEST SCORE MUST BE RANKED #2, AND SO FORTH. IN THIS CASE, THERE IS ONLY ONE NEW APPLICATION.

CONTINUATION APPLICATIONS ARE REVIEWED BY A PANEL OF COMMISSION MEMBERS WHO ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR ASSESSING GRANT PERFORMANCE. USING A RUBRIC FOR SCORING, THEY CONSIDER PERFORMANCE INDICATORS (ENROLLMENT, RETENTION, 30-DAY ON TIME, ETC.), COMPLIANCE, ACHIEVEMENT OF PERFORMANCE MEASURE TARGETS, FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE AND SPONSOR AUDIT, AND MORE. BASED ON THE RESULTS, THE COMMISSIONERS HAVE THE OPTION TO SUPPORT THE REQUEST AS SUBMITTED OR REDUCE THE REQUEST OR DENY THE REQUEST/END THE GRANT. UNDER MAINE STATE PROCUREMENT RULES, NO RANKING IS PERMITTED FOR CONTINUATIONS OF MULTI-YEAR GRANTS.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
THE MARYLAND GOVERNOR'S OFFICE ON SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERISM (GOSV) IS PROUD TO PRESENT THIS PACKAGE OF SEVEN CONTINUATION APPLICATIONS FOR THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE'S (CNCS) 2018 AMERICORPS STATE AND NATIONAL GRANT COMPETITION. THESE PROGRAMS WILL ENGAGE 366.17 MSYS, INVEST $1.7 MILLION IN FEDERAL AMERICORPS FUNDS, AND LEVERAGE $3.5 MILLION IN STATE AND LOCAL FUNDS IN MARYLAND COMMUNITIES. 
THIS PACKAGE IS THE RESULT OF EXTENSIVE APPLICATION REVIEW AND REFINEMENT CONDUCTED BY THE GOSV STAFF AND THE MEMBERS OF THE MARYLAND GOVERNOR'S COMMISSION ON SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERISM (GCOSV) BETWEEN SEPTEMBER 11, 2017 AND JANUARY 16, 2018. TOGETHER, THESE PROGRAMS WILL ADDRESS CNCS PRIORITIES IN THE AREAS OF ADDRESSING THE OPIOID AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG ABUSE CRISIS, ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT FOR STUDENTS IN TWO OF THE LOWEST PERFORMING SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN MARYLAND (BALTIMORE CITY AND PRINCE GEORGE'S COUNTY), ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, CAPACITY BUILDING FOR NONPROFIT SERVICE AGENCIES, HEALTH AND NUTRITION SERVICES FOR YOUTH, AND MORE.
THESE APPLICATIONS REPRESENT PROGRAMS THAT WILL SERVE EVERY CORNER OF THE STATE AND ENGAGE DIVERSE AMERICORPS MEMBERS AND LOCAL VOLUNTEERS IN TACKLING THE MOST CRITICAL HUMAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL NEEDS OF MARYLAND COMMUNITIES. THEY WILL ALSO PROVIDE TRANSFORMATIONAL AMERICORPS SERVICE EXPERIENCES AND SIGNIFICANT ORGANIZATIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR HOST SITE PARTNER AGENCIES. EACH OF THE SEVEN CONTINUATION PROGRAMS HAS A STRONG TRACK RECORD AND MEETS OR EXCEEDS CNCS-REQUIRED ANNUAL FUNDING MATCH LEVELS FOR THE AMERICORPS GRANTS. FROM THE RESEARCH-BASED, TRAUMA-INFORMED STRATEGIES OF OUR NEW TARGETED PRIORITY PROGRAMS, HOPECORPS AND COAT TO THE STATE-WIDE REACH OF THE MARYLAND CONSERVATION CORPS AND VOLUNTEER MARYLAND, TO THE TARGETED COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT WORK OF CIVIC WORKS, AND THE INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO IMPROVING STUDENT ACHIEVEMENT AND ENGAGEMENT OF READING PARTNERS AND TEACH FOR AMERICA, THESE PROGRAMS PROVIDE INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS THAT ENGAGE HUNDREDS OF LOCAL COMMUNITY PARTNERS, PUBLIC OFFICIALS, AND FUNDERS, AND THOUSANDS OF COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS. WITH THE BREADTH OF THE ISSUES ADDRESSED, THESE PROGRAMS WILL ALSO IMPACT THE HEALTH OF COMMUNITIES AND CITIZENS BEYOND MARYLAND'S BORDERS (E.G. CHESAPEAKE BAY WATERSHED, PROFESSIONAL VOLUNTEER MANAGEMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, GREEN ENERGY, ORGANIC AND SUSTAINABLE FARMING, AND MORE).

READING ASSIST INSTITUTE PROPOSES TO HAVE 20 AMERICORPS MEMBERS (RAI CORPS) WHO WILL PROVIDE INTENSIVE ONE-TO-ONE STRUCTURED LITERACY INTERVENTIONS TO 120 STUDENTS IN GRADES 1-3, LOCATED AT NINE (9) LOW-INCOME, HIGH-NEED ELEMENTARY SCHOOL SITES IN NEW CASTLE COUNTY, DE. ARKANSAS SERVICE COMMISSION, THE ARKANSAS COMMISSION ADMINISTERS 12 AMERICORPS PROGRAMS THAT ADDRESS THE STATE'S NEEDS IN THE AREAS OF: EDUCATION, HEALTHY FUTURES; ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY, ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. IN ADDITION, THE COMMISSION IS DEDICATED TO IMPROVING THE QUALITY OF EFFICIENCY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF NON-PROFITS IN ARKANSAS.

SERVE ALABAMA IS SUBMITTING ONE STATE FORMULA-FIXED AMERICORPS GRANT APPLICANT WHICH IS TEACH FOR AMERICA - ALABAMA. THE UPCOMING PROGRAM YEAR WILL BE THEIR SIXTH YEAR AS A COMMISSION GRANTEE. THEY ARE SUBMITTING AN APPLICATION FOR 46 MSY WITH A TOTAL COST OF $46,000. NO MATCHING FUNDS ARE REQUIRED.

IF A PROPOSAL MET THE MINIMUM CRITERIA, IT WAS REVIEWED AND SCORED BY TWO READERS SELECTED BY THE COMMISSION. THESE READERS WERE ASKED TO AGREE ON A CONSENSUS SCORE SHEET THAT WAS USED TO RANK PROPOSALS. THE SCORE SHEET ALIGNED WITH THE OUTLINE AND POINTS VALUES SPECIFIED IN THE NEW YORK STATE RFP.  IF THE TWO READERS COULD NOT COME TO CONSENSUS, A THIRD READER WAS ASKED TO REVIEW THE PROPOSAL AND TO WORK WITH THE ORIGINAL TWO READERS TO SUBMIT A CONSENSUS SCORE SHEET.   THE REVIEWERS THEN SUBMITTED THEIR CONSENSUS SCORE SHEETS FOR EACH PROPOSAL TO THE COMMISSION WHICH WERE RANKED ACCORDING TO SCORE FROM HIGHEST TO LOWEST. AFTER EVALUATING THE PROPOSALS, THE COMMISSION RECOMMENDED THE TOP 40 PERCENT OF ALL PROPOSALS SCORED FOR FUNDING TO THE CORPORATION, AS THE PROGRAMMING PROPOSED WOULD INCREASE GEOGRAPHIC DIVERSITY OF THE STATE'S AMERICORPS PORTFOLIO, INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES TO SERVE IN AMERICORPS AND/OR TO RECEIVE AMERICORPS SERVICES, OR FOCUS ON A NEED NOT OTHERWISE ADDRESSED IN ITS AMERICORPS PROGRAMMING.

THIS PRIME APPLICATION CONSISTS OF 1 RECOMPETE APPLICATION, THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI (UM) COLLEGE CORPS, REQUESTING $800 PER MSY: $20,320 IN CNCS FUNDS TO SUPPORT 120 MINIMUM TIME MEMBERS. UM ESTIMATES THAT IT EXPENDS $80,000 IN CASH AND INKIND RESOURCES TO EFFECTIVELY OPERATE THIS PROGRAM, AND BELIEVES ANY FUNDS EXPENDED ON THIS PROGRAM ARE A NECESSARY INVESTMENT.  
    THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI (UM), IN COLLABORATION WITH MISSISSIPPI UNIVERSITY FOR WOMEN (MUW), THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI, AND A NEW PARTNERSHIP WITH DELTA STATE UNIVERSITY, WILL ENGAGE 120 COLLEGE STUDENTS AS MINIMUM TIME EAP MEMBERS (25.4 MSYS) WHO ENHANCE SERVICES PROVIDED BY SCHOOLS AND NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS IN THE COMMUNITIES SURROUNDING UM, MUW, AND DSU.  COLLEGE CORPS (CC) MEMBERS SERVING THROUGH UM AND MSU WILL CONTINUE TO DELIVER THE JUMPSTART CURRICULUM TO 180 PREK CHILDREN, AND MEMBERS IN THE UM REGION WILL TUTOR 25 STUDENTS IN GRADES 1-4.

SUPPORTING AND IMPLEMENTING AMERICORPS PROGRAMS TO SERVE THE PEOPLE OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF KENTUCKY IS THE PERFECT SEGUE FOR THE KENTUCKY COMMISSION ON COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERISM AND SERVICE (KCCVS) TO ACCOMPLISH ITS MISSION STATEMENT:  "ENGAGING KENTUCKIANS IN VOLUNTEERISM AND SERVICE TO POSITIVELY IMPACT OUR COMMUNITIES".    
 PRIOR TO POSTING THE REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS (RFP), KCCVS ANNOUNCED THE OPPORTUNITY TO APPLY FOR AN AMERICORPS GRANT TO SERVE THEIR COMMUNITY ON THE KCCVS WEBSITE WHEN THE DRAFT NOFO WAS RELEASED ON SEPTEMBER 3, 2013 AS WELL AS SHARING WITH THE KCCVS DISTRIBUTION LIST FOR ITS NEWSLETTER AND SEVERAL OTHER COMMUNICATION AVENUES INCLUDING A PRESS RELEASE FROM THE CABINET FOR HEALTH AND FAMILY SERVICES. THE INFORMATION WAS ALSO SENT TO THE COMMISSION'S EMAIL DISTRIBUTION LIST.
A TIMELINE FOR THE REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS WAS DEVELOPED WITH AN "EMAIL OF INTENT TO APPLY" DUE TO THE COMMISSION BY NOVEMBER 1, 2013.  ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WAS PROVIDED TO THE POTENTIAL APPLICANTS AS RESOURCES WERE MADE AVAILABLE BY CNCS (FAQS, PERFORMANCE MEASURE, REVISED NOFO, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CALLS).
      DUE TO ISSUES WITH EGRANTS, THE PRIME APPLICATIONS IN EGRANTS WAS OPENED ON NOVEMBER 14, 2013.  KCCVS RECOMMENDED THAT PROGRAMS CREATE WORD DOCUMENTS OF THEIR NARRATIVES WHILE WAITING PRIMES.
      THOSE RESPONDING WITH AN "INTENT TO APPLY" EMAIL WERE OFFERED AN OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE IN ONE-ON-ONE TRAINING WITH THE PROGRAM OFFICER OR TO HAVE A DISCUSSION BY CONFERENCE CALL ON THE INTRICACIES OF COMPLETING AN AMERICORPS GRANT APPLICATION. SEVERAL OF THE POTENTIAL APPLICANTS AVAILED THEMSELVES TO THE OPPORTUNITY.  
APPLICATIONS WERE DUE ON NOVEMBER 27, 2013. STAFF REVIEWED THE APPLICATIONS NOVEMBER 29-DECEMBER 2, 2013 FOR REQUIRED CONTENT. APPLICATIONS WERE REVIEWED BY A PANEL OF COMMISSIONERS AND COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS ON DECEMBER 3, 2013.  IN RESPONSE TO THE RFP: 
-	THREE (3) NEW REIMBURSABLE APPLICATIONS WERE RECEIVED AS WELL AS THREE (3)  REIMBURSABLE CONTINUATIONS; AND
-	TWO (2) FIXED PRICE CONTINUATIONS.
      THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE CONVENED THE MORNING OF DECEMBER 4TH TO FINALIZE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE FULL COMMISSION WHICH MET LATER THAT DAY. THE COMMITTEE REVIEWED, RANKED AND PRIORITIZED ALL OF THE SUBMITTED AMERICORPS*STATE APPLICATIONS.  THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE DECIDED TO RECOMMEND IMMEDIATELY TWO OF THE THREE SUBMITTED REIMBURSABLE NEW APPLICATIONS; ALL OF THE CONTINUATION APPLICATIONS; AND CONDITIONALLY ONE OF THE NEW APPLICATIONS BASED ON A FULL REWRITE AND SECOND REVIEW BY THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE TO THE COMMISSION FOR SUBMISSION TO CNCS FOR POSSIBLE COMPETITIVE FUNDING.  
       THE COMMISSION DISCUSSED, CONCURRED AND APPROVED PROGRAM COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS.
       THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE REVIEWED THE CONDITIONALLY APPROVED APPLICATION AND APPROVED IT FOR SUBMISSION ON JANUARY 3, 2014.
THIS APPLICATION IS FOR NEW, RECOMPETING, OR CONTINUATION COMMISSION APPLICANTS, INCLUDING TERRITORIES WITH COMMISSION, APPLYING FOR FIXED AMOUNT GRANTS (INCLUDING EAP).

WASHINGTON CAMPUS COMPACT C/O WESTERN WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY PROPOSES TO PLACE 60 FULL-TIME AMERICORPS MEMBERS ON 37 COLLEGE CAMPUSES TO RECRUIT, TRAIN, AND SUPPORT 600 COLLEGE STUDENT VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE AS COLLEGE ACCESS COACHES TO 4,500 ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED (ED) 4TH-12TH GRADE YOUTH IN SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY-BASED AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS THROUGHOUT THE STATES OF WASHINGTON AND OREGON. MEMBERS AND VOLUNTEER COACHES WILL PROVIDE A MINIMUM OF 15 HOURS OF INTERVENTIONS TO THE ED YOUTH. AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR: 1) INCREASING ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT OF ED YOUTH, 2) INCREASING ACADEMIC PREPAREDNESS FOR POST-SECONDARY EDUCATION OF ED YOUTH, 3) INCREASING KNOWLEDGE ABOUT COLLEGE OPTIONS AND THE COLLEGE EXPERIENCE AMONG ED YOUTH AND THEIR FAMILIES, AND 4) INCREASING KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HOW TO APPLY TO AND PAY FOR POST-SECONDARY EDUCATION AMONG ED YOUTH AND THEIR FAMILIES. IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE AN ADDITIONAL 1,200 VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN NATIONAL DAYS OF SERVICE OR OTHER COMMUNITY SERVICE EVENTS.
THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $771,000 WILL BE MATCHED WITH $923,520 IN LOCAL AND STATE PUBLIC FUNDING AND $260,480 IN PRIVATE FUNDING.

THE STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION (SCA) PROPOSES TO HAVE 30 AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL PRESERVE, PROTECT, AND INCREASE ENERGY EFFICIENCY ON PUBLIC LANDS AND STRUCTURES, WHILE EDUCATING VISITORS TO ENVIRONMENTALLY-CONSCIOUS BUILDING PRACTICES WITH LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL PARTNERS INCLUDING THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, NATIONAL FOREST SERVICE, AND THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE.  AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR IMPROVING 160 ACRES OF PUBLIC LANDS, FOR IMPROVING OVER 95 MILES OF HISTORIC TRAILS AND WATERWAYS, AND COMPLETING 12 HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROJECTS.  IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE AN ADDITIONAL 90 VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROJECTS.
THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREA OF ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AND THE USER FOCUS AREA OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION.  THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $370,500 WILL BE MATCHED WITH $318,017 IN PUBLIC FUNDING.

THE SERVICE AND CONSERVATION CORPS PROPOSES TO HAVE 44 FT AND 32 HT/SERVING FOR 6 MONTHS IN A FULL-TIME CAPACITY (60 MSYS), USING 6 TOTAL CREWS, WITH TYPICALLY 10 MEMBERS EACH WHO WILL PROVIDE DISASTER RELIEF, GULF COAST RESTORATION, AND CONSERVATION OF PUBLIC LANDS IN 4 STATES (AR, LA, OK, TX). AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AC MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR 675 ACRES OF IMPROVED PUBLIC LAND AND 27 MILES OF IMPROVED TRAILS/WATERWAYS. IN ADDITION, THE AC MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE AN ADDITIONAL 500 VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN ASSISTING IN DISASTER AREAS AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS THROUGH NATIONAL TRAILS DAY AND MLK DAY.
     THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREAS OF ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $805,800 WILL BE MATCHED WITH $1,013,172, $903,172 IN PUBLIC FUNDING AND $110,000 IN PRIVATE FUNDING.

FOODCORPS PROPOSES TO HAVE 138 FULL-TIME AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL CONNECT CHILDREN TO HEALTHY FOOD IN LIMITED-RESOURCE PUBLIC SCHOOLS BY TEACHING NUTRITION EDUCATION, BUILDING AND TENDING SCHOOL GARDENS, AND PROMOTING LOCALLY GROWN FOOD IN CAFETERIAS IN ARIZONA, ARKANSAS, CALIFORNIA, GEORGIA, IOWA, MAINE, MICHIGAN, NEW MEXICO, NORTH CAROLINA, OREGON, AND WASHINGTON, DC. AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR MEASURABLY IMPROVING CHILDREN'S PREFERENCE FOR AND BEHAVIOR TOWARD EATING HEALTHY FOODS, THEREBY OVERCOMING A KEY BARRIER IN ADDRESSING THE NATION'S COSTLY EPIDEMIC OF CHILDHOOD OBESITY AND OTHER DIET-RELATED DISEASES. IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE AN ADDITIONAL 4,150 VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN PROMOTING HEALTHY FOODS TO CHILDREN AND SUPPORTING LONG-TERM, HEALTHY CHANGES TO THE SCHOOL FOOD ENVIRONMENTS THAT AFFECT CHILDREN'S DIETARY BEHAVIOR.
THIS PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREA OF HEALTHY FUTURES. THE CNCS FIXED AMOUNT INVESTMENT OF $1,423,884 WILL BE MATCHED WITH $3,928,170 IN PRIVATE FUNDING FROM INDIVIDUALS, CORPORATE PARTNERS, AND PRIVATE FOUNDATIONS, INCLUDING COMMITMENTS ALREADY SECURED VIA THE W.K. KELLOGG FOUNDATION AND WILLIAM K. BOWES FOUNDATION.

ON APRIL 7, 2014, THE WASHINGTON COMMISSION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE (WCNCS) ISSUED APPLICATION INSTRUCTIONS TO ITS FORMULA SUBGRANTEES.  ALL APPLICANTS WERE PERFORMING SATISFACTORILY AND CURRENTLY IN YEAR ONE OR TWO OF A THREE-YEAR FUNDING CYCLE.  THEREFORE, ALL WERE ELIGIBLE TO APPLY FOR CONTINUATION FUNDING FOR THE 2014-2015 PROGRAM YEAR.  
BECAUSE FEDERAL FUNDING WAS EXPECTED TO BE FLAT OR ONLY A MODEST INCREASE, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE COMMISSION WOULD NOT ACCEPT APPLICATIONS FROM PROSPECTIVE NEW APPLICANTS THIS YEAR SINCE CONTINUATION APPLICANTS WOULD UTILIZE THE ENTIRE ALLOCATION.  IF EXCESS FUNDS WERE AVAILABLE, PRIORITY WOULD BE GIVEN TO RESTORE FUNDING TO SUBGRANTEES THAT HAD EXPERIENCED A REDUCTION IN THE PRIOR YEAR AS A RESULT OF SEQUESTRATION AND UN-FUNDED COMPETITIVE PROGRAMS BEING ABSORBED IN THE FORMULA PORTFOLIO.  
STAFF CONDUCTED A BIDDER'S MEETING ON APRIL 14, 2014 TO GIVE APPLICANTS AN OPPORTUNITY TO SEEK CLARIFICATION ON ITEMS CONTAINED IN THE APPLICATION INSTRUCTIONS.  APPLICATIONS WERE DUE TO WCNCS ON APRIL 30, 2014.  
ON APRIL 10, CNCS INFORMED WCNCS ITS FORMULA ALLOCATION FOR FY14 WAS $2,482,319.  IN ADDITION, WCNCS WILL REALLOCATE $70,000 OF UNEXPENDED DOLLARS.  IN FY14, A TOTAL OF $2,552,319 IS AVAILABLE FOR FORMULA GRANTS.   
THE COMMISSION RECEIVED A TOTAL OF TEN CONTINUATION APPLICATIONS; FOUR APPLICANTS ARE APPLYING FOR FUNDING FOR YEAR TWO AND SIX ARE APPLYING FOR YEAR THREE.  COMMISSION STAFF CONFIRMED THAT ALL APPLICATIONS CONTAINED THE NECESSARY COMPONENTS AND WERE SUBMITTED BY THE REQUIRED DEADLINE OF APRIL 30, 2014.  CONTINUATION APPLICATIONS ARE NOT REQUIRED TO UNDERGO THE PEER REVIEW PROCESS.  COMMISSION STAFF CONDUCTED A COMPLIANCE AND BUDGET REVIEW. 
FUNDING FOR MOST PROGRAMS WAS RECOMMENDED AT CURRENT LEVELS WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE NORTHWEST LEADERSHIP FOUNDATION (NWLF).  GIVEN THE SIGNIFICANT REDUCTION LAST YEAR, STAFF RECOMMENDED THAT THE BALANCE OF EXCESS FUNDING BE AWARDED TO THE NWLF TO BRING THIS UP TO PAR WITH OTHER PROGRAMS.  IN TOTAL, STAFF RECOMMENDED THAT TEN PROGRAMS BE FUNDED TOTALING $2,552,319 TO SUPPORT 200.52 MEMBER SERVICE YEARS (257 POSITIONS).    
THE STAFF RECOMMENDATIONS WERE APPROVED BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE AND REPORTED TO THE FULL COMMISSION DURING THE MEETING ON MAY 30, 2014.  DUE TO THE LACK OF A QUORUM, AN ELECTRONIC VOTE WAS CAST IN WHICH COMMISSIONERS APPROVED THE STAFF RECOMMENDATION.

MISSOURI COMMUNITY SERVICE COMMISSION, THE MISSOURI SERVICE COMMISSION, WILL PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES WITH COMMISSION INVESTMENT FUNDS:  INCREASE AMERICORPS SERVICES IN RURAL-UNDERSERVED AREAS OF OUR STATE, INCREASE COLLABORATION AND CROSS STREAM PARTNERSHIP STRENGTHEN SUB GRANTEES ABILITY TO CONDUCT HIGH QUALITY PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENT AND EVALUATION IN ORDER TO IMPROVE PROGRAM PERFORMANCE AND BUILD EVIDENCE, THE MISSOURI COMMISSION IS REQUESTING $200,894.00 TO SUPPORT TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES.

SUPPORTING AND IMPLEMENTING AMERICORPS PROGRAMS TO SERVE THE PEOPLE OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF KENTUCKY IS THE PERFECT SEGUE FOR THE KENTUCKY COMMISSION ON COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERISM AND SERVICE (KCCVS) TO ACCOMPLISH ITS MISSION STATEMENT:  "ENGAGING KENTUCKIANS IN VOLUNTEERISM AND SERVICE TO POSITIVELY IMPACT OUR COMMUNITIES".    
 PRIOR TO POSTING THE REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS (RFP), KCCVS ANNOUNCED THE OPPORTUNITY TO ATTEND ONE OF 6 COLLOQUIUMS TO BE HELD ALL OVER THE COMMONWEALTH TO PROVIDE A FORUM FOR A DISCUSSION OF COMMUNITY NEEDS AND TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON THE AMERICORPS RFP. 
SEPTEMBER 25, 2012, THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE OF THE COMMISSION MET TO AFFIRM ITS STATE PRIORITIES AND ADDITIONAL GUIDANCE FOR ITS AMERICORPS PORTFOLIO.  THE GUIDANCE WAS DISCUSSED AND APPROVED AT THE FULL COMMISSION MEETING LATER THAT DAY.
 INFORMATION REGARDING THE AVAILABILITY OF FUNDING FOR NEW AMERICORPS PROGRAMS WAS MADE AVAILABLE.  THE INFORMATION WAS ALSO SENT TO THE COMMISSION'S EMAIL DISTRIBUTION LIST AND POSTED ON THE KCCVS WEBSITE.
      THE PRIME APPLICATIONS IN EGRANTS WAS OPENED ON OCTOBER 29, 2012.  WE ASKED ALL INTERESTED PARTIES TO SUBMIT AN EMAIL OF "INTENT TO APPLY" BY NOVEMBER 5, 2012.
      THOSE RESPONDING WITH AN "INTENT TO APPLY" EMAIL WERE OFFERED AN OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE IN ONE-ON-ONE TRAINING WITH THE PROGRAM OFFICER OR TO HAVE A DISCUSSION BY CONFERENCE CALL ON THE INTRICACIES OF COMPLETING AN AMERICORPS GRANT APPLICATION. SEVERAL OF THE POTENTIAL APPLICANTS AVAILED THEMSELVES TO THE OPPORTUNITY.  APPLICATIONS WERE DUE ON DECEMBER 7, 2012. STAFF REVIEWED THE APPLICATIONS DECEMBER 10-11, 2012 FOR REQUIRED CONTENT. APPLICATIONS WERE REVIEWED BY A PANEL OF COMMISSIONERS AND COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS ON DECEMBER 12, 2012.  IN RESPONSE TO THE RFP: 
-	SIX (6) FIXED-PRICE GRANTS WERE RECEIVED -- FOUR (4) NEW, AND TWO (2) RECOMPETING;
-	FIVE (5) REIMBURSABLE APPLICATIONS WERE RECEIVED -- THREE (3) NEW, AND TWO (2) CONTINUATIONS; 
-	ONE (1) RECOMPETING EDUCATION AWARD ONLY PROGRAM.
      THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE CONVENED THE MORNING OF DECEMBER 13TH TO FINALIZE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE FULL COMMISSION WHICH MET LATER THAT DAY. THE COMMITTEE REVIEWED, RANKED AND PRIORITIZED ALL OF THE SUBMITTED AMERICORPS*STATE APPLICATIONS.  THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE DECIDED TO RECOMMEND IMMEDIATELY THREE (3) OF THE SIX (6) SUBMITTED FIXED-PRICED APPLICATIONS, TWO (2)  OF THE THREE (3) SUBMITTED REIMBURSABLE APPLICATIONS; AND THE RECOMPETING EDUCATIONAL AWARD PROGRAM TO THE COMMISSION FOR SUBMISSION TO CNCS FOR POSSIBLE COMPETITIVE FUNDING.  THREE OF THE SUBMITTED FIXED GRANT APPLICATIONS WERE CONDITIONALLY APPROVED UPON A TOTAL REWRITE AND REVIEW WITH SCORING.  AS THE RESULT OF THE REWRITING, TWO APPLICATIONS WERE ACCEPTED FOR SUBMISSION AND ONE WAS INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN THE FORMULA RFP WHEN IT IS ISSUED.
       THE COMMISSION DISCUSSED, CONCURRED AND APPROVED PROGRAM COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS. THE UNAPPROVED APPLICATION WERE INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN THE COMMISSION'S FORMULA COMPETITION LATER IN THE YEAR.
	THE FORMULA REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS OPENED JUNE 17, 2013 AFTER THE COMPETITIVE GRANT AWARDS WERE KNOWN.  UN-AWARDED COMPETITIVE GRANT PROPOSALS WERE ELIGIBLE TO PARTICIPATE AS WELL AS APPLICATIONS THAT WERE RECOMMENDED FOR FORMULA COMPETITION AFTER THE COMPETITIVE GRANT REVIEW.  THE RFP CLOSED JUNE 26, 2013.  THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE MET ON JUNE 28, 2013 TO REVIEW APPLICATIONS AND MAKE THEIR RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE COMMISSION.  THE COMMISSION WAS CONVENED BY CONFERENCE CALL BY THE CHAIR AND THE PROGRAM COMMITTEE MADE THEIR RECOMMENDATIONS. THE RECOMMENDATIONS WERE ACCEPTED AND APPROVED BY THE COMMISSION.
	THE RESULTS ARE KCCVS WILL BE FUNDING 2 REIMBURSABLE CONTINUATIONS, AND 1 NEW REIMBURSABLE PROGRAM AND 4 FIXED GRANTS (INCLUSIVE OF AN EAP) FOR THE COMING PROGRAM YEAR ADDRESSING RECOGNIZED COMMUNITY NEEDS IN THE COMMONWEALTH.
N/A

THE DELAWARE COMMISSION IS SUBMITTING TWO APPLICATIONS THAT INCLUDE ONE APPLICATION FOR A CURRENTLY ESTABLISHED SUB-GRANTEE AMERICORPS PROGRAM AND ONE NEW SUB-GRANTEE.
THE PROGRAMS ARE READING ASSIST INSTITUTE AND KUUMBA ACADEMY WHICH BOTH HAVE AN EDUCATION FOCUS
BOTH ORGANIZATIONS ARE ADDRESSING COMPELLING COMMUNITY NEEDS UNIQUE TO DELAWARE AND ARE IN LINE WITH THE STATE SERVICE PLAN.  THE FOUR PROGRAMS ADDRESS THE FOCUS AREAS OF DISASTER SERVICES, EDUCATION, AND HEALTHY FUTURES

ALABAMA STATE AMERICORPS HAS A PRESENCE IN ALL 67 ALABAMA COUNTIES. SERVE ALABAMA WILL SUBMIT SEVEN APPLICANTS FOR AMERICORPS STATE FORMULA FUNDING AND ONE FORMULA FIXED. OF THE SUBMISSION, ONE IS NEW (PREVIOUS GRANTEE). THE FOCUS AREAS OF THESE APPLICANTS INCLUDE EDUCATION, ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY, DISASTER PREPAREDNESS AND CAPACITY BUILDING.
NO APPLICABLE.

2017
THE VIRGINIA SERVICE COMMISSION PROPOSES TO HAVE 165 COMPETITIVELY-FUNDED AMERICORPS MEMBERS (71.87 MSY) WHO WILL SERVE ACROSS THE STATE IN HALIFAX, PITTSYLVANIA, HENRY, MARTINSVILLE, DANVILLE, ARLINGTON, HAMPTON, NEWPORT NEWS, AND RICHMOND.  AT THE END OF THE FIRST PROGRAM YEAR, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR PROVIDING LITERACY- AND STEM-RELATED TUTORING, READING INSTRUCTION FOR 3RD ? 5TH GRADERS, ACADEMIC AND CAREER READINESS, YOUTH VOLUNTEERISM AND SERVICE, AND PREVENTION OF STUDENT DISENGAGEMENT, AND SUPPORT EMPLOYMENT, HOUSING, AND ADDICTION RECOVERY SERVICES.  IN ADDITION, THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL LEVERAGE MORE THAN 2500 VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL BE ENGAGED IN SIMILAR ACTIVITIES.
THE PROGRAMS WILL FOCUS ON THE CNCS FOCUS AREAS OF EDUCATION AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY, AND INCLUDE STEM ACTIVITIES AND OPIOID/HEROIN (AND OTHER ADDICTIONS) RECOVERY ACTIVITIES.  THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $969,060 WILL BE MATCHED WITH A TOTAL OF $875,362 IN PUBLIC AND PRIVATE FUNDING.

THE SOUTH CAROLINA COMMISSION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE IS IS HOSTED BY THE UNITED WAY ASSOCIATION OF SOUTH CAROLINA AND FUNCTIONS AS A STANDING COMMITTEE OF THAT BODY.
THE COMMISSION IS GOVERNED BY A BODY OF TWENTY FOUR COMMISSIONERS, TWO OF WHOM ARE APPOINTED BY THE GOVERNOR.  WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A CORPORATION REPRESENTATIVE (NON-VOTING) THE BALANCE OF THE COMMISSION ARE RECRUITED FROM AROUND THE STATE AND REPRESENT EDUCATION, BUSINESS, LABOR, STATE GOVERNMENT AND VARIOUS NONPROFIT ENTITIES SHARING STATE-WIDE RESPONSIBILITIES AND INTERESTS.
PROGRAM STAFF CONSISTS OF SEVEN INDIVIDUALS WITH BROAD AND DIVERSE AREAS OF EXPERIENCE AND EXPERTISE WHO DEDICATE VARYING AMOUNTS OF TIME TO PROGRAM OPERATIONS AND SUPPORT.

SERVE RHODE ISLAND IS SUBMITTING FOUR NEW COMPETITIVE APPLICATIONS FOR CONSIDERATION IN THE 2012-2015 AMERICORPS FUNDING CYCLE AND SIX CONTINUATION APPLICATIONS (ALL FOR A SECOND YEAR OF COMPETITIVE FUNDING). ALL THESE PROPOSALS ADDRESS NATIONAL FOCUS AREAS AND ADDRESS RHODE ISLAND'S STATE SERVICE
PLAN AND THE COMMISSION'S STRATEGIC PLAN.
